section.title: Abstract
section.para: Cities function as complex adaptive systems formed through the interplay of decentralized bottom-up self-organization and centralized top-down planning interventions. Rogue City Designer is a procedural generation framework that models this duality through:

listitem.para: Tensor field axioms encoding top-down planning intent (radial, grid, organic)
AESP-based district emergence from road network topology (Access, Exposure, Serviceability, Privacy)
Multi-scale street analysis using persistent homology and grid quality metrics
Layered graph support for bridges, tunnels, and grade-separated infrastructure

section.para: Unlike traditional square-grid generators, this system produces coherent, believable urban environments ranging from rigid Manhattan-style grids to organic European networks, based on axiom configuration and urban complexity principles.

section.title: Urban Complexity Framework
section.para: Cities exhibit **organized complexity**‚Äîa balance between chaos (overstimulation, incoherence) and order (sterility, monotony). The framework evaluates this balance through:

listitem.para: Network Density: Nodes, intersections, edges per unit area
Network Resilience: Functionality under disruption (blocked streets, damage)
Network Connectedness: Path diversity, permeability, routing options

section.title: Grid Quality Metrics
section.para: The generator evaluates street networks using a composite grid index balancing four components:

section.title: 1. Straightness (œÇ)
section.para: $$\varsigma = \frac{\text{average great-circle distance}}{\text{average segment length}}$$
Measures how closely streets approximate straight lines, affecting navigation efficiency and visual coherence.

section.title: 2. Orientation Order (Œ¶)
section.para:
Analyzes internal consistency of street orientations through:
Calculate bidirectional compass bearings of every street
Compute street orientation entropy
Normalize as orientation order indicator
High order ‚Üí consistent grid patterns (Manhattan) Low order ‚Üí organic networks (medieval European)

section.title: 3. Terrain Adaptation
section.para: Evaluates variance and inconsistency as roads adapt to slopes, elevation changes, and natural obstacles.

section.title: 4. Four-Way Intersection Proportion (I)
section.para: $$I = \frac{\text{four-way intersections}}{\text{total intersections}}$$
Tracks the share of nodes that are four-way junctions, influencing traffic flow and grid character.
$$\text{GridIndex} = (\varsigma \times \Phi \times I)^{1/3}$$
The geometric mean ensures non-compensatory aggregation‚Äîpoor performance in any component significantly impacts the final score.

section.title: Frontage Profile Components
section.para: Roads are scored on four dimensions that determine adjacent land use:

listitem.para: Access (A): Ease of vehicular/pedestrian entry
Exposure (E): Visual prominence and visibility
Serviceability (S): Capacity for deliveries, utilities
Privacy (P): Seclusion from public thoroughfare

section.title: District Classification
section.para: The generator converts Frontage Profiles (AESP) into district-type affinities using weighted formulas reflecting urban planning principles:

listitem.para: Character: Versatile neighborhoods combining residential, commercial, light industrial
Buildings: Mid-rise apartments with ground-floor retail, live-work lofts, mixed-use towers
Height: 3-8 stories
Features: Active street frontage, pedestrian-friendly, diverse architecture
Character: Housing-focused areas prioritizing privacy and quality of life
Buildings: Single-family homes, townhouses, apartment complexes, condos
Height: 1-6 stories
Features: Setbacks with landscaping, lower density, recreational spaces
Character: Business and retail areas maximizing visibility and foot traffic
Buildings: Storefronts, shopping centers, office buildings, hotels
Height: 2-20+ stories
Features: Large display windows, prominent signage, minimal setbacks
Character: Public/institutional areas serving community-wide functions
Buildings: Government buildings, libraries, museums, schools, hospitals
Height: 2-12 stories
Features: Monumental architecture, plazas, symbolic design, accessibility
Character: Production, manufacturing, logistics areas requiring heavy service access
Buildings: Warehouses, factories, distribution centers, utilities
Height: 1-4 stories
Features: Large footprints, truck access, rail sidings, utilitarian design

section.title: Practical Application
section.para:
When processing a parcel, the lot generator:
Queries nearest road type using distance-to-segment calculations
Retrieves road's frontage profile (A, E, S, P values)
Applies district formulas to generate affinity scores
Combines with axiom biases and influencer landmarks
Uses classification to inform building height, setback, density, ground-floor use
Emergent Result: Buildings along highways exhibit industrial/commercial characteristics (high service, low privacy), while cul-de-sacs spawn residential structures (high privacy, low exposure).

section.title: Portals
section.para: A portal is a vertex shared by ‚â•2 layers (edges adjacent belong to different layers). Conceptually, there are m copies of ‚Ñù¬≤, one per layer, glued together at portals. This layered space is denoted L.
